sub_title: Lecturer-Researcher at HAS University of Applied Sciences / Researcher in Climate Biology
summary:
My understanding of biology, ecology, earth and (past) climate enable me to think critically about a sustainable future for humanity and nature.

Research Scientist and Lecturer with a Doctoral degree in (Arctic) Climate Biology. 

Experienced coach, speaker and teacher.

Broadly interested in many other fields of art, philosophy and technology.

(50 year jubilee Symposium of Labaratory of Palynology and Paleoecology [http://lpp-foundation.nl/] and associated groups)', 'issuer': 'Labaratory of Palynology and Paleoecology', 'date': {'month': 6, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}}, {'title': 'Challenge: Business Marathon Energy Finallist', 'description': "All over the world people are increasingly living in cities and urban areas. Cities are becoming more densely populated and the question arises: how do we maintain a good quality of life, which is sustainable, healthy, clean and comfortable? One important aspect in this context is the production and consumption of energy in buildings and houses, for lights, heating, cooling, machinery and the like.

With ongoing innovations in sustainable energy technologies, making them more powerful and reliable, the use of fossil energy finally is on the decline. The price of sustainable energy is dropping below that of fossil in various places in the world, even with the current oil prices, giving a huge boost to the energy transition.

However, big challenges pop up, now that the experimental age is over and cities, countries and entire continents want to switch to this renewable energy source. How are we going to transform our current landscape and manage the ‘smart energy grid’, where local energy produced from sun, wind and water needs to be coordinated with energy consumption at different locations, at different times during the day?

The Business Marathon Energy is about these new challenges, set in the urban context. Going from real cases and problems, as brought in by the Challenge Partners, teams create innovative solutions and working prototypes in a 3-day 'hackathon', with 3 semi-finalists going for pitches on the main stage and win the big prize.", 'issuer': 'Campus Party', 'date': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}]

projects:
[{'title': 'Challenge: Business Marathon Energy', 'date': {'start': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2016}, 'end': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2016}}, 'description': "
All over the world people are increasingly living in cities and urban areas. Cities are becoming more densely populated and the question arises: how do we maintain a good quality of life, which is sustainable, healthy, clean and comfortable? One important aspect in this context is the production and consumption of energy in buildings and houses, for lights, heating, cooling, machinery and the like.

With ongoing innovations in sustainable energy technologies, making them more powerful and reliable, the use of fossil energy finally is on the decline. The price of sustainable energy is dropping below that of fossil in various places in the world, even with the current oil prices, giving a huge boost to the energy transition.

However, big challenges pop up, now that the experimental age is over and cities, countries and entire continents want to switch to this renewable energy source. How are we going to transform our current landscape and manage the ‘smart energy grid’, where local energy produced from sun, wind and water needs to be coordinated with energy consumption at different locations, at different times during the day?

The Business Marathon Energy is about these new challenges, set in the urban context. Going from real cases and problems, as brought in by the Challenge Partners, teams create innovative solutions and working prototypes in a 3-day 'hackathon', with 3 semi-finalists going for pitches on the main stage and win the big prize.

Specialized in the interaction between living nature and the atmospheric forces that steer weather, I worked with the latest approaches and techniques, mainly biological. During this project, I worked towards the publication of several peer-reviewed articles and ultimately bundled them in my doctoral dissertation. Working as a PhD-candidate granted me the opportunity to independently develop myself and my project, while under guidance of my doctoral advisors. For this research project, the planning and managing of time, money, energy, people and resources was very important. The experience gained through extensive fieldwork campaigns in extreme environments and long lab-work sessions contributed greatly to my understanding of the living and physical world. I also supervised and lead Master and Bachelor students in their thesis projects and associated lab- and fieldwork. \n\nhttps://www.uu.nl/staff/FEZErcan', 'title': 'PhD Researcher', 'employment_type': 'year': 2015}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Utrecht en omgeving, Nederland', 'date': {'start': {'month': 6, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}, 'end': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}}, 'company': 'Utrecht University', 'description': 'The Toarcian Oceanic Anoxic Event (T-OAE) (ca. 182 Myr, Early Jurassic) represents one of the best-recognized examples of greenhouse warming, decreased seawater oxygenation and mass extinction. The lack of abundant data about the T-OAE from outside of the European Epicontinental Seaway (EES) has led to substantial debate about the spatial extent and ecological features outside the EES. The unique chance to palynologically analyse Kelimyar River Outcrop Section S-16 from North Siberia, consisting of Late-Pliensbachian to Early-Toarcian successions covering the T-OAE, gives the opportunity to unveil additional characteristics of the event outside the EES. The in earlier studies proposed order of events of the T-OAE in terms of sea-level rise and global warming is largely supported by the palynology from this study. Analysis of both the marine and terrestrial palynology revealed a strong transition from a situation dominated by terrestrial input to a marine dominated signal at the Pliensbachian-Toarcian transition, signifying a fast sea-level rise at the onset of the T-OAE. Increase in a representation of species associated with humid conditions represents the warming that occurred during the T-OAE. The abundant presence of dinoflagellate cysts during the T-OAE indicates the lack of a ‘dinocyst blackout’ that occurred in the EES at the time of the event. The dinoflagellate genus Batiacasphaera appears earlier in this section the High Arctic than previously known from other locations.', 'title': 'Research Project: Toarcian Oceanic Anoxic Event in Northern Siberia', 'employment_type': 'Internship'}, {'location': 'Utrecht en omgeving, Nederland', 'date': {'start': {'month': 11, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}, 'end': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}}, 'company': 'Utrecht University', 'description': 'During my bachelor’s and master’s I assisted in two bachelor courses at Utrecht University: ‘Palaeoecology’ and ‘Environmental change through time’. My primary task lay in guiding bachelor students during diverse computer practicals, palynologycal microscope practicals, and hands-on (fossil)plant practicals.', 'title': 'Teaching Assistant', 'employment_type': 'Contract'}, {'location': 'Utrecht en omgeving, Nederland', 'date': {'start': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}, 'end': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}}, 'company': 'Utrecht University', 'description': 'Annual resolution needle length and cuticle property data have been obtained from needles of bristlecone pine, Pinus longaeva, from the White Mountains, California, USA. The bristlecone pine, living at the tree line in extreme alpine conditions is known for its longevity, some individuals are the world’s oldest non-clonal organisms. The bristlecone pine’s suitability for annual resolution studies is unique because the tree holds on to the needles longer than any other plant and the needles grow in annual fascicles that are clearly distinguishable. In the present study a continuous 44 years long series of annual needle-length and structural stomatal conductance have been analyzed from individual trees in extreme low P[CO2]-conditions and are compared to long and short term climate variability as well as global atmospheric P[CO2] change. Distinct annual needle-length variations corresponded highly among eight different individual trees that were sampled. In this data-set, two signals are distinguished, an overall declining trend in needle length and an annual variability. The declining long-term trend provides evidence for a negative correlation between atmospheric P[CO2] concentration and needle-length. The annual variation relates to summer temperature and reflects the dominant climate system in the area, the PDO (Pacific Decadal Oscillation) which describes humidity and temperature regimes in the northern Pacific region. Our results for the first time demonstrate needle-length dependence on P[CO2] and temperature. A strong decline in structural stomatal conductance shows a strong response to changes in atmospheric P[CO2] and quantifies stomatal plasticity under near glacial P[CO2] not studied in-situ so far.', 'title': 'Research Project: CO2 Stomatal Response and Needle Length-Climate Relations in Bristlecone Pines.', 'employment_type': 'Internship'}]}, {'company': {'id': 342134, 'name': 'NIOZ Royal Netherlands Institute for Sea Research', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/D4E0BAQF-Kr4jHb8MPA/company-logo_400_400/0/1689670615280?e=1700697600&v=beta&t=U5NjZzOaaE7CK08eT9JQUe9D99XXFQwzwbAF09TYQp0', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/company/nioz-royal-netherlands-institute-for-sea-research/', 'employees': {'start': 201, 'end': 500}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}, 'end': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Texel', 'date': {'start': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}, 'end': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}}, 'company': 'NIOZ Royal Netherlands Institute for Sea Research', 'description': 'A multidisciplinary Marine Sciences program, based on the integration of marine physics, marine (bio)chemistry, marine (micro)biology and marine geology was recently lacking in The Netherlands. Yet, given the major role of the oceans in climate processes, as a resource for food, chemicals, and energy, as a source of biodiversity and as a means of transport, the potential of such an integrated programme is clear. To fill this gap, the University of Amsterdam (UvA), the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU), Groningen University (RUG), Utrecht University (UU) and the marine institutes NIOZ Royal Netherlands Institute for Sea Research, present a national programme in Marine Sciences, which is based on existing master and bachelor programs with a substantial marine component.', 'title': 'NIOZ Marine Master
